instruction: What kinds of spectrum was used to detect E. coli and S. typhimurium on the surface of food processing facilities?
Output: The researchers used fluorescence spectrum to detect E. coli and S. typhimurium on the surface of food processing facilities.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to detect E. coli and S. typhimurium on the surface of food processing facilities?
Output: Partial least-squares regression (PLSR) and principal component analysis (PCA) were used as spectral feature processing methods to detect E. coli and S. typhimurium on the surface of food processing facilities.

instruction: What metric was chosen to detect E. coli and S. typhimurium on the surface of food processing facilities?
Output: Fluorescence hyperspectral imaging was chosen to detect E. coli and S. typhimurium on the surface of food processing facilities.

instruction: What were the results of the discriminant analyses performed to identify and classify coupons with bacteria in the study assessing the feasibility of using fluorescence hyperspectral imaging to detect E. coli and S. typhimurium on the surface of food processing facilities?
Output: The results of the discriminant analyses performed in the study showed that the discriminant performances of specificity and sensitivity for E. coli and S. typhimurium were over 90% for most machine learning models used. The highest performances were generally obtained from the k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) model. This indicates that the machine learning models were effective in identifying and classifying coupons on which bacteria could be cultured. The application of the learning model to the hyperspectral image confirmed that the biofilm detection was well performed, suggesting the possibility of rapidly inspecting biofilms using fluorescence hyperspectral images.

instruction: Can fluorescence hyperspectral imaging be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for detecting Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Salmonella typhimurium (S. typhimurium) on the surface of food processing facilities?
Output: Yes. Based on the information provided in the related study, fluorescence hyperspectral imaging can be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for detecting Escherichia coli (E. coli) and Salmonella typhimurium (S. typhimurium) on the surface of food processing facilities. The study found that fluorescence hyperspectral imaging, combined with machine learning models, achieved high discriminant performances of specificity and sensitivity for both E. coli and S. typhimurium. The highest performances were generally obtained from the k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) model. The application of the learning model to the hyperspectral image confirmed that biofilm detection was well performed. This indicates the possibility of rapidly inspecting biofilms using fluorescence hyperspectral images, suggesting its superiority over traditional methods for detecting these bacteria on the surface of food processing facilities.
